body: Is this like the parameter handle_unknown{‘error’, ‘ignore’}, default=’error’ in sklearn's one hot encoder?

Thanks for asking!

Not quite: handle_unknown governs everything that happens for categories not seen in the train set. However, the encoders that we have in dirty-cat can deal with those, as long as they are strings.

Rather, it would be to deal with NaNs, which encode missingness.

Can I take a look at it? I maybe a little slow on fixing it though. 

I have yet to read your study, but is it adequate to encode all missing values with the same encoding (0) and assume they will be handled downstream or better to encode them as unique categories?

I looked briefly at the code (similarityencoder), and the sklearn function _check_X() throws the error when there are NaNs. Would a reasonable solution be to impute the NaNs with a special value (for e.g. __nan__) before this check, and then handle later on to encode to 0?

It would be great if you'd work on this!!!

I indeed think that the simplest way to embed missing values would be to cast them to a vector of zeros.

Now, with regards to how to implement this, we are hitting a few problems.

I had a quick look, and it seems that, for the SimilarityEncoder at least, replacing nans by the empty string '' works (though it spits out nasty warnings that we should capture at the right place, ie as deep as possible).

```
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

a = [['a',    'b'],
     ['b',    'a'],
     ['b',    np.nan],
     ['a',    'c'],
     [np.nan, 'a'],
    ]

from dirty_cat import SimilarityEncoder
se = SimilarityEncoder()

X = se.fit_transform(pd.DataFrame(a).fillna(value=''))
```

We could start with this strategy, and do a first PR for the similarity? Note that I don't think that the solution that I coded (using pd's fillna) should be implemented on all types of input. We might have to have a different treatment if the input is a list, and yet another if it is a numpy array.

Also, if this strategy ends up working for other of our encoders (eg the MinHashEncoder) we should probably introduce a subclass of _BaseEncoder that does this transformation in the _check_X method.

I'll have a look ASAP. One thing to note: if the dtype is string or unicode, there cannot be nans. So you don't need to coerce, you can just move on without worrying about nans/missing values. This will be the most efficient approach.

Can you send a pull request (make in "work in progress" if it's not finished). It will be easier to comment on it.

Rather than using a masked array, wouldn't something it be faster to do something like:
```
X[mask] = self.handle_missing
```

body:
Hi @GaelVaroquaux , I checked the implementation of MinHashEncoder, here's what I found:

Line 186 checks if the first element in X is not a string. I think this could be extended for any element in X.
assert isinstance(X[0], str), "ERROR: Input data is not string."

Imputing missing values with a blank string '' does not work, since it is later computing the ASCII/UTF-8 value for the char, and throws an error then. 

It seems like just improving the assertion above could be the right fix?

The assertion could certainly be improved. Firstly, if the input is an array and has a dtype of kind 'U' or 'S' (check .dtype.kind), we now that its fine: it's an array and cannot have nans.

Then, to handle nans, I would suggest to modify the get_hash method and handle nans. The challenge is that this method is called in a very tight loop and hence should be as fast as possible. I think that see ways of refactoring this in a better way. Are you up for this? In which case we should schedule a call.
Yes, I can give it a shot. We can connect this weekend, if that works for you.

Sounds good for this week end. I'm actually packed with work until Saturday. Thanks a lot!

You'll tell me what time suits you. I was planning to go hiking on Saturday morning (my time), but I can probably squeeze something in before I leave.

Thanks heaps!

We can do Sunday, if Saturday does not work for you. I'm available both days, 10:30 AM - 9:30 PM (IST). I am not sure what time zone you are in, so go ahead and set one up in that window, and also what you suggest we can use to connect. I am on Skype/Google etc.  I'm also on the scikit gitter channel.
